In Côte d'Ivoire, Alassane Ouattara wins a fourth term, marking the twilight of his rule
subhead: With more than 89% of the vote, Ivorian President Alassane Ouattara secured a fourth term on October 27, according to results announced by the Independent Electoral Commission. The presidential election held on Saturday took place against the backdrop of a tightly controlled political landscape.
byline: By Anna Sylvestre-Treiner (Abidjan (Côte d'Ivoire) special correspondent)

title: Lithuania closes its border with Belarus
Jamaica braces for mass destruction as Hurricane Melissa churns in
Cholera returns to Haiti as thousands of displaced people survive under 'catastrophic conditions'
subhead: Since the start of the year, the infectious disease has affected more than 3,000 people and caused 53 deaths, mostly in the greater Port-au-Prince area.
byline: By Jean-Michel Hauteville (Pétion-Ville and Port-au-Prince (Haiti), special correspondent)

title: Sudan’s paramilitary forces seize el-Fasher, army’s last Darfur stronghold
subhead: Military chief General Abdel-Fattah Burhan said on Monday that military officers decided to withdraw from the city entirely in hopes of sparing the civilian population from further violence. Medical groups reported dozens of civilians killed.

title: Acclaimed jazz drummer Jack DeJohnette, who worked with Miles Davis, dies at 83
subhead: The musician died on Sunday in Kingston, New York, of congestive heart failure. Over the years, he collaborated with a vast array of jazz greats, among them Keith Jarrett, Stan Getz and Thelonious Monk.

title: Zohran Mamdani leads New York mayoral race, rattling Democratic establishment
subhead: A week before the vote, the self-proclaimed socialist leads the polls after a savvy campaign on the cost of living. But his stance to the left of the party unsettles even his own camp, while questions linger over the funding of his social platform.
byline: By Nicolas Chapuis (New York (United States) correspondent)

title: 'The Louvre's stolen jewels, valuable only for their gemstones, are above all outdated and cumbersome'
subhead: Reactions to the Louvre heist ignore the complex equation museums face: offering generous public access while securing cumbersome objects better suited for a bank vault, explains Le Monde columnist Michel Guerrin.

title: Orson Welles, the magician of all media at the Cinémathèque française
subhead: Forty years after the titan's death and 110 years after his birth, a major exhibition and retrospective offer a portrait of this brilliant jack-of-all-trades who endlessly blurred the lines between truth and fiction.
